ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the foundations of decision under uncertainty, arbitrage pricing, complete markets, portfolio choice problem, and mean-variance analysis.
Basic asset pricing theory and models.

Theoretical asset-pricing models, taught by Professor Ingersoll in the first half, and their application to real-world data and implications on long-run risk/habits/disasters and term structures, taught by Professor Giglio in the second half.
Key components for building and understanding asset pricing models

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength: covered a large amount of relevant material. weakness: sometimes it was too fast-paced
Very well taught in the second half (Giglio); he actually cares about his students
Good lectures, good notes, would have liked problem sets in the first half.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want to learn asset pricing and financial economics, that's the course you should take.
Yes, if you want the challenge of a core course in the finance PhD sequence at Yale SOM.
Absolutely, as it was by far the most engaging course I took that semester.
